1714.90.text:
So to get started I'm going to poke that through
to the back, and weave it in back here.

1719.25.text:
And if you're using a wool yarn that's going
to be sticky and stick to itself, and not

1724.53.text:
be machine washed, you can just do a regular
weaving in in garter stitch.

1730.00.text:
I'll give you a link to the video I have on
that right here.

1733.21.text: This is the super secure way.

1736.40.text:
I'm going to just weave this in, just a couple
of stitches.

1745.47.text:
And then, this is where the fancy trick comes
in.

1748.11.text: I'm going to untwist the plies, half and half.

1753.43.text:
And this is actually a wool yarn, that is
clearly sticky!

1758.25.text: And doesn't need to be woven in like this.

1761.82.text: If I wanted it to be really secure, I could.

1764.05.text:
This is a two ply yarn, I've separated the
plies, two and two.

1769.13.text:
I'm going to thread half of those plies on
the tapestry needle.

1773.78.text: And then just take that half a stitch away.

1777.41.text:
So that the two ends are coming out of places
right next to each other.

1783.16.text: Then tie a double knot with those two ends.

1792.66.text:
Don't break the yarn, just shy of breaking
the yarn really.

1800.96.text: And I can cut it really short.

1802.75.text:
And it can go in the washing machine, and
it's almost invisible.

1806.98.text: That's it, the Ten Stitch Blanket.

1812.11.text:
Many thanks to Frankie for letting us use
her pattern in this tutorial.
